post: BRI Senior Fellow, Tony Williams, recently interviewed author James Graham Wilson to examine the life and legacy of Paul Nitze, a key architect of Cold War national security policy. Drawing from his book Americas Cold Warrior: Paul Nitze and National Security from Roosevelt to Reagan, Wilson explores how Nitzes decades-long public service reflected a deep commitment to American ideals and the defense of liberty in the nuclear age. Watch it today!  https://bit.ly/4mfNXwe

How do Bill of Rights Institute classroom resources and programs prepare students for their future? Anthony Simone shares how we help young people develop valuable life skills that will serve them in their communities and throughout their careers.  https://lnkd.in/eX5xTPSn

Saturday, July 19, was the anniversary of the first womens rights convention in U. S. history opened in Seneca Falls, New York. Organized by leaders like Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Lucretia Mott, the convention brought together reformers, including Frederick Douglass, to demand equal rights for women. Attendees signed the Declaration of Sentiments, boldly declaring that all men and women are created equal,  and calling for womens suffrage and full civic equality. Find out more in our recent YouTube short! http://bit.ly/3TOCqYz

Congratulations to Vick Tan! His project, Fish Hut, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that brings fishing and education to underserved kids in his community, earned an Honorable Mention award in our 2025 MyImpact Challenge. Star Spangled Tea, an affiliate partner of BRI, has over a dozen tea blends that have nods to historical figures and local flavors. Whether you're a history buff or a tea lover, use code 'BRI1791' to get a discount and support the Bill of Rights Institute with every purchase. A portion of your purchase helps us bring free civic education to classrooms nationwide. Visit  https://bit.ly/46ald2T to shop now.
